description.short: Measures vulnerability to attackers who exploit rapport, similarity, and liking to bypass security verification and decision-making processes
description.context: When employees develop positive rapport with individualsâ€”through perceived similarity, attractiveness, or reciprocal interestâ€”they become more likely to trust and comply with requests, creating a neurochemical vulnerability that attackers exploit through social media reconnaissance, rapport-building techniques, and extended engagement campaigns.
description.impact: Organizations with high susceptibility experience successful long-term social engineering campaigns, insider threat cultivation, and targeted spear phishing. Research shows 300-400% increased attack success rates when rapport is established before exploitation.
description.psychological_basis: Cialdini's Liking Principle (1984) - people say yes to those they like. Neurologically, positive social interactions trigger oxytocin and dopamine release while suppressing amygdala threat detection, creating trust bias that overrides security protocols. Attachment theory explains rapid bonding through similarity and reciprocity.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Relationship-independent verification protocols consistently applied. Social media monitoring prevents reconnaissance. Training includes rapport detection and Kevin Mitnick-style social engineering scenarios. Personal relationships do not override security procedures.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Some awareness of liking-based attacks but inconsistent verification when rapport exists. Limited social media monitoring. Basic training exists but doesn't specifically cover rapport-building attacks or similarity exploitation.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Strong cultural emphasis on being friendly and helpful. No protocols for relationship-independent verification. Social media profiles expose extensive personal information. Employees view skepticism of friendly individuals as rude or paranoid.

rule_based.formula: R_3.4(t) = 1 if (E_duration > 7 days AND S_similarity > 0.6 AND V_verification = 0), else 0
rule_based.description: Binary detection when extended engagement with high similarity occurs without verification

E_duration.calculation: Days between first and most recent interaction with external contact
E_duration.query: SELECT DATEDIFF(MAX(timestamp), MIN(timestamp)) as E_duration FROM communications WHERE sender_external=true GROUP BY sender_id

S_similarity.calculation: Similarity score from shared attributes mentioned in communications
S_similarity.query: SELECT similarity_score FROM sentiment_analysis WHERE similarity_markers > 3 AND time_window='30d'

interaction_frequency.calculation: Number of interactions per day with external contact
interaction_frequency.query: SELECT COUNT(*)/DATEDIFF(MAX(timestamp),MIN(timestamp)) FROM communications WHERE sender_external=true GROUP BY sender_id

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Relationship-Independent Verification Protocols
items.question: When employees have developed positive working relationships or friendships with external contacts, vendors, or partners, are security verification procedures still consistently applied for sensitive requests?

options.label: Verification protocols are relationship-independent and consistently applied regardless of rapport, familiarity, or liking
Employees skip verification for people they know, like, or have positive relationships with

items.evidence_required: Relationship-independent verification policy, audit logs showing verification regardless of sender relationship

items.title: Social Media Reconnaissance Surface
items.question: What visibility do employee social media profiles provide to potential attackers conducting reconnaissance for similarity exploitation?

options.label: Employees maintain privacy-focused social media with limited personal information disclosure
Some employees share personal information but receive periodic guidance on privacy
Employees extensively share personal details (hobbies, family, locations, interests) with no privacy guidance

items.evidence_required: Sample employee social media profiles, social media security policy, privacy training records
items.soc_mapping: Social media monitoring logs, public profile exposure metrics

items.title: Rapport-Building Attack Training
items.question: What specific training do employees receive on recognizing and defending against rapport-building social engineering attacks?

options.label: Regular training includes Kevin Mitnick-style rapport attacks, similarity exploitation scenarios, and long-game social engineering
Generic awareness training mentions being friendly to strangers but no specific rapport attack scenarios
No training on rapport-building attacks or emphasis on 'customer service' and being friendly

items.evidence_required: Training curriculum with rapport attack scenarios, completion records, simulation results

items.title: Personal Information Disclosure in Professional Settings
items.question: How much personal information do employees typically share with external contacts during business interactions (conferences, calls, emails)?

options.label: Employees maintain professional boundaries with limited personal disclosure
Some personal sharing for relationship building but general awareness of boundaries
Culture encourages personal connection through extensive sharing of hobbies, family, background

items.evidence_required: Observed communication examples, cultural assessment, information disclosure policy

items.title: Similarity and Shared Background Awareness
items.question: How do employees respond when external contacts emphasize shared backgrounds, interests, or connections (alma mater, hometown, mutual friends)?

options.label: Employees recognize similarity emphasis as potential manipulation tactic and maintain verification protocols
Some awareness but similarity creates positive bias
Shared backgrounds create immediate trust and rapport that reduces skepticism

items.evidence_required: Employee interviews about similarity responses, training on similarity exploitation
items.soc_mapping: S_similarity metric, similarity_markers from sentiment analysis

items.title: Extended Engagement Campaign Detection
items.question: Does your organization monitor for and detect extended relationship-building campaigns by external parties over weeks or months before making requests?

options.label: Systems monitor external engagement patterns and flag gradual relationship building before sensitive requests
No monitoring for extended engagement campaigns or long-game social engineering

items.evidence_required: Extended engagement detection system, monitoring dashboards, alert examples

items.title: Conference and In-Person Interaction Security
items.question: What security protocols exist for employees who meet potential attackers at conferences, networking events, or social gatherings?

options.label: Formal protocols for conference interactions including information disclosure limits and followup verification requirements
General guidance but no specific protocols for in-person rapport building
No protocols for conference security or employees encouraged to network freely

items.evidence_required: Conference security protocol, employee guidance materials, post-conference verification procedures
items.soc_mapping: Conference badge scan logs, post-event communication tracking

items.title: Friendliness Culture vs Security Rigor
items.question: How does organizational culture balance being friendly and helpful with maintaining security skepticism?

options.label: Culture explicitly supports being friendly while maintaining security verification - both are valued equally
Some tension between friendliness and security with unclear guidance
Security skepticism viewed as unfriendly or paranoid - strong cultural preference for helpfulness

items.evidence_required: Cultural assessment, employee feedback on security vs friendliness balance
items.soc_mapping: Incident reports where friendliness led to security bypass

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: When employees have positive working relationships or friendships with vendors, partners, or regular external contacts, do they still verify unusual requests from these individuals?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific examples of verification despite positive relationships, clear policy requiring relationship-independent verification
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some verification but employees admit skipping it for 'trusted' contacts
scoring_guidance.red: Trust replaces verification for liked individuals - 'we know them' justification

followups.text: Can you describe a recent example where someone verified a request from a contact they had a positive relationship with?
What happens when an employee says 'I trust this person, I don't need to verify'?

items.text: How do employees typically respond when someone emphasizes shared backgrounds, interests, or connections during business interactions?

scoring_guidance.green: Employees recognize similarity emphasis as potential manipulation, maintain professional skepticism
scoring_guidance.yellow: Similarity creates positive feelings but some awareness of potential manipulation
scoring_guidance.red: Shared backgrounds immediately create trust and reduce verification

followups.text: Has anyone ever mentioned their alma mater or hometown to build rapport with your employees? How did they respond?
Do your employees receive training on how attackers use similarity to build trust?

items.text: What guidance or policies exist regarding employee social media profiles and the personal information they share publicly?

scoring_guidance.green: Active social media monitoring program, privacy guidance, regular reviews of employee exposure
scoring_guidance.yellow: General privacy awareness but no specific guidance or monitoring
scoring_guidance.red: No social media security guidance or employees extensively share personal details

followups.text: Can we look at a few employee LinkedIn or social media profiles to assess information disclosure?
Has anyone ever mentioned that external contacts knew personal details that could only come from social media reconnaissance?

items.text: How much personal information do employees typically share during business calls, emails, or conference interactions?

scoring_guidance.green: Clear professional boundaries with minimal personal disclosure, training on information boundaries
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some personal sharing for relationship building but generally bounded
scoring_guidance.red: Culture encourages extensive personal sharing to build relationships and rapport

followups.text: What would employees typically talk about at a conference or networking event with someone they just met?
Are there explicit guidelines on what personal information should not be shared in professional settings?

items.text: Does your organization have the capability to detect extended relationship-building campaigns where external parties engage employees over weeks or months before making requests?

scoring_guidance.green: Active monitoring of external engagement patterns, behavioral analytics detecting gradual rapport building
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some awareness but no systematic detection capability
scoring_guidance.red: No monitoring for extended engagement or employees view long relationships as validation

followups.text: Have you ever had a situation where someone built a relationship over time before making a suspicious request?
What systems or processes would detect someone who emails an employee weekly for 2 months before requesting sensitive access?

items.text: What specific training do employees receive on Kevin Mitnick-style social engineering where attackers invest significant time building rapport before exploitation?

scoring_guidance.green: Comprehensive training including long-game scenarios, rapport detection, defensive techniques
scoring_guidance.yellow: Generic social engineering training but no specific rapport-building attack scenarios
scoring_guidance.red: No training on extended social engineering campaigns

followups.text: Can you show us training materials that specifically cover rapport-building attacks?
Have you conducted simulations where friendly external contacts gradually build trust before making requests?

items.text: What security protocols exist for employees attending conferences, networking events, or other settings where in-person rapport building occurs?

scoring_guidance.green: Formal conference security protocols, information disclosure limits, followup verification requirements
scoring_guidance.yellow: General 'be careful' guidance but no specific protocols
scoring_guidance.red: Employees encouraged to network freely with no security protocols

followups.text: After employees meet new contacts at conferences, what verification is required before granting those contacts access or information?
Do you track or monitor business cards collected or LinkedIn connections made at conferences?

solutions.title: Relationship-Independent Verification Protocols
solutions.description: Implement verification procedures that explicitly apply regardless of relationship quality, familiarity, or liking
solutions.implementation: Policy stating 'verification is required even for long-term trusted contacts when requests are unusual'; automated systems require verification checkboxes before sensitive actions
solutions.technical_controls: Verification enforcement in approval workflows, relationship-agnostic security rules, compliance monitoring

solutions.title: Social Media Monitoring and Privacy Program
solutions.description: Monitor employee social media exposure and provide privacy guidance to reduce reconnaissance surface
solutions.implementation: Regular social media profile audits, privacy best practices training, automated monitoring for high-risk information disclosure
solutions.technical_controls: Social media monitoring tools, privacy scoring, automated alerts for excessive disclosure

solutions.title: Rapport-Building Attack Training
solutions.description: Comprehensive training on Kevin Mitnick-style rapport attacks including similarity exploitation, extended engagement, and neurochemical trust bias
solutions.implementation: Quarterly simulations of rapport-building attacks, training on oxytocin/dopamine manipulation, similarity recognition exercises
solutions.technical_controls: Simulation platform with rapport scenarios, training completion tracking, competency assessments

solutions.title: Extended Engagement Detection System
solutions.description: Deploy behavioral analytics to detect long-game social engineering campaigns building rapport over weeks or months
solutions.implementation: Monitor external communication patterns, flag gradual relationship building before sensitive requests, analyze sentiment progression
solutions.technical_controls: UEBA platform, sentiment analysis, relationship timeline visualization, anomaly detection

solutions.title: Conference and In-Person Interaction Protocols
solutions.description: Establish security procedures for conferences, networking events, and in-person rapport building
solutions.implementation: Pre-conference briefings, information disclosure limits, post-conference verification requirements for new contacts, badge scan tracking
solutions.technical_controls: Conference contact database, followup verification workflows, connection monitoring

solutions.title: Similarity and Reciprocity Awareness Training
solutions.description: Train employees to recognize and resist similarity exploitation and reciprocity manipulation
solutions.implementation: Specific modules on Cialdini's liking principle, similarity markers (alma mater, hometown, hobbies), attractiveness halo effects
solutions.technical_controls: Training platform with liking principle scenarios, knowledge assessments, behavioral tests

solutions.title: Friendly-Skeptical Culture Development
solutions.description: Build organizational culture that balances friendliness with security skepticism without conflict
solutions.implementation: Leadership communication that verification is respectful not rude, recognition programs for maintaining security with friendly individuals, 'trust but verify' cultural messaging
solutions.technical_controls: Cultural assessment surveys, incident reporting encouraging both friendliness and verification
